meanings.def: similar to somebody/something
examples: She's wearing a dress like mine.
He's very like his father.
She looks nothing like (= not at all like) her mother.
That sounds like (= I think I can hear) him coming now.
It tastes rather like chicken.

meanings.def: used to ask somebody’s opinion of somebody/something
examples: What's it like studying in Spain?
This new girlfriend of his—what's she like?

meanings.def: in the same way as somebody/something
examples: Students were angry at being treated like children.
He ran like the wind (= very fast).
You do it like this.
I, like everyone else, had read these stories in the press.
Don't look at me like that.
(informal) The candles are arranged like so (= in this way).
This chart provides a comparison of the ways that teenage boys and girls in the UK spend their free time.
In many cases, the results for boys and girls are virtually the same/identical.
In many cases, the results for boys are virtually the same as/identical to the results for girls.
Both boys and girls spend the bulk of their free time with friends.
Most of the boys do more than two hours of sport a week, as do many of the girls.
Like many of the girls, most of the boys spend a large part of their free time using the internet.
The girls particularly enjoy using social networking websites. Similarly, nearly all the boys said they spent at least two to three hours a week on these sites.
The dark wood shone like glass.
Stop acting like a spoilt child.

meanings.def: for example
examples: anti-utopian novels like ‘Animal Farm’ and ‘1984’
He has blue eyes like me.
She enjoys all kinds of music, as I do.
Repeat these five steps, as in the last exercise.
Nobody understands him like I do.
I don’t want to upset him again like before.
It looks like we’re going to be late.

meanings.def: used to show what is usual or typical for somebody
examples: It's just like her to tell everyone about it.

meanings.def: used to give a number or an amount that is more accurate than one previously mentioned
examples: He believes the figure should be more like $10 million.

meanings.def: better; more acceptable
examples: This is more like it! Real food—not that canned muck.

meanings.def: used to give what you think is a better description of something
examples: Just talking? Arguing more like it.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has done something annoying, silly, etc.
examples: Oh, what am I like? I just completely forgot it.

idioms.def: used to give a number or an amount that is more accurate than one previously mentioned
examples: He believes the figure should be more like $10 million.
This is more like it! Real food—not that canned muck.
Just talking? Arguing more like it.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody has done something annoying, silly, etc.
examples: Oh, what am I like? I just completely forgot it.

related: like a cat on hot bricks
like a cat on a hot tin roof

meanings.def: similar to; typical of
examples: childlike
shell-like

meanings.def: to find somebody/something pleasant, attractive or of a good enough standard; to enjoy something
examples: like somebody/something She's nice. I like her.
I really like him.
Do you like their new house?
Which tie do you like best?
How did you like Japan (= did you find it pleasant)?
She's never liked swimming.
I don't like the way he's looking at me.
She liked the idea of being her own boss.
The company didn't like the fact that I'd taken maternity leave.
You've got to go to school, whether you like it or not.
like doing something We like having people to stay.
like somebody/something doing something I didn't like him taking all the credit.
(formal) I didn't like his taking all the credit.
like to do something I like to see them enjoying themselves.
like it when… I like it when you do that.
Why are you wanting a new phone when your current one works perfectly well?
What shall we do tonight? I’m thinking bowling.
I’m loving the weather today!
Do you like their new house?
I like to see them enjoying themselves.
He loved the way she smiled.
We were fond of the house and didn’t want to leave.
I’m not keen on spicy food.
She’s not keen on being told what to do.
She adores working with children.
I love you.
She’s nice. I like her.
I’ve always been very fond of your mother.
It’s obvious that she adores him.
They are devoted to their children.
He cared for her more than she realized.
He dotes on his children.
I don't like the sound of that.
‘I don't like the look of him,’ Christopher whispered to Joseph.
Everyone he met instantly liked him and wanted to be friends.
He pretended to like her for Tony's sake.
He works hard and is well liked by his colleagues.
I have always liked Sue and I don't intend to stop now.
I hope you will get to like our town.
I liked him enormously and was sorry when he left.
I personally liked this song a lot.
I really like that restaurant.
I tried to like her because it would be for the best.
I wanted to like the movie because of its message.
I'm learning to like spinach.
She guessed that he secretly liked wearing skirts.
Which story do you like best?
a man who was universally liked
He never did like me much, did he?
I like it in Spain.

meanings.def: used with would or should as a polite way to say what you want or to ask what somebody wants
examples: like something Would you like a drink?
like to do something I'd like to think it over.
I would like to thank you all for coming tonight.
Would you like to come with us?
(formal) We would like to apologize for the delay.
Would you like to see the rest of the house?
How can they afford it? That's what I'd like to know.
like somebody/something to do something We'd like you to come and visit us.
like for somebody to do something (North American English) I'd like for us to work together.
Would you like a cup of coffee?
We’re going to a club tonight. Do you want to come with us?
Could I have a glass of water, please?
Do you have any decaffeinated coffee?
I'd like tea with sugar, please.
I'll have the pasta with salad, please.
Certainly.
I'm sorry, we don't have any left.
Yes, of course. Here you are/​go.

meanings.def: to prefer to do something; to prefer something to be made or to happen in a particular way
examples: like to do something At weekends I like to sleep late.
like something + adj. I like my coffee strong.

meanings.def: used in negative sentences to mean ‘to be unwilling to do something’
examples: not like to do something I didn't like to disturb you.
not like doing something He doesn't like asking his parents for help.

meanings.def: to want
examples: Do what you like—I don't care.
You can dye your hair whatever colour you like.

meanings.def: if you like something on social media, a news website, a blog, etc. you show that you agree with it or that you think it is good by clicking a special button
examples: By the next morning, over twenty of my friends had liked my new profile picture.
Over seven hundred Facebook users have already liked the company’s website.

meanings.def: used to emphasize that something bad has happened to you and you want some sympathy
examples: How would you like it if someone called you a liar?

meanings.def: used to politely agree to something or to suggest something
examples: ‘Shall we stop now?’ ‘If you like.’
If you like, we could go out this evening.
‘Let's go and see “The Last Samurai.”’ ‘OK, if you like.’
You can come too if you like.

meanings.def: used when you express something in a new way or when you are not confident about something
examples: It was, if you like, the dawn of a new era.

meanings.def: used to protest that something that has been said is not true or fair
examples: ‘She called you a cheat.’ ‘Well, I like that!’

meanings.def: used to say that you hope or believe that something is true
examples: I like to think I'm broad-minded.
I’d like to think that you were helping me because you wanted to, not because you felt you had to.

meanings.def: used to say that something is very good or you enjoy it
examples: You get paid to eat chocolate. So what's not to like?
I love a good bagel—what’s not to like?

idioms.def: used to emphasize that something bad has happened to you and you want some sympathy
examples: How would you like it if someone called you a liar?

idioms.def: used to politely agree to something or to suggest something
examples: ‘Shall we stop now?’ ‘If you like.’
If you like, we could go out this evening.
‘Let's go and see “The Last Samurai.”’ ‘OK, if you like.’
You can come too if you like.
It was, if you like, the dawn of a new era.

idioms.def: used to protest that something that has been said is not true or fair
examples: ‘She called you a cheat.’ ‘Well, I like that!’

idioms.def: used to say that you hope or believe that something is true
examples: I like to think I'm broad-minded.
I’d like to think that you were helping me because you wanted to, not because you felt you had to.

idioms.def: used to say that something is very good or you enjoy it
examples: You get paid to eat chocolate. So what's not to like?
I love a good bagel—what’s not to like?

meanings.def: the things that you like
examples: We all have different likes and dislikes.
He is more than happy to discuss his life, his likes and his career.
She is very cosmopolitan in her likes and attitudes.

meanings.def: a person or thing that is similar to another
examples: jazz, rock and the like (= similar types of music)
I let the apartment to students, backpackers and such like.
a man whose like we shall not see again
They experienced a period of expansion the like of which the world had rarely seen.
You're not comparing like with like.

meanings.def: if something on social media, a news website, a blog, etc. receives a like, it means that somebody has shown that they agree with it or think it is good by clicking a special button
examples: The band now has thousands of likes.

meanings.def: used to refer to somebody/something that is considered as a type, especially one that is considered as good as somebody/something else
examples: She didn't want to associate with the likes of me.

idioms.def: used to refer to somebody/something that is considered as a type, especially one that is considered as good as somebody/something else
examples: She didn't want to associate with the likes of me.

meanings.def: in the same way as
examples: No one sings the blues like she did.
It didn't turn out like I intended.
Like I said (= as I said before), you're always welcome to stay.

meanings.def: as if
examples: She acts like she owns the place.

meanings.def: having similar qualities to another person or thing
examples: a chance to meet people of like mind (= with similar interests and opinions)
She responded in like manner.

meanings.def: used in very informal speech, for example when you are thinking what to say next, explaining something, or giving an example of something
examples: It was, like, weird.
It was kind of scary, like.
It's really hard. Like I have no time for my own work.

meanings.def: used in very informal speech to show that what you are saying may not be exactly right but is nearly so
examples: I'm leaving in like twenty minutes.
It's going to cost like a hundred dollars.

meanings.def: used in very informal speech, to mean ‘I say’, ‘he/she says’, etc.
examples: And then I'm like ‘No Way!’

meanings.def: used in informal speech instead of as to say that something happens in the same way
examples: There was silence, but not like before.
He has blue eyes like me.
She enjoys all kinds of music, as I do.
Repeat these five steps, as in the last exercise.
Nobody understands him like I do.
I don’t want to upset him again like before.
It looks like we’re going to be late.

meanings.def: quite probably
examples: She would be in bed by now, as like as not.
She would be in bed by now, as like as not.
